t: Proverbs 16
The*pn preparations of the heart belong*i to man, But*ld the answer of the tongue is*i from the Lord.*s
All*ln the ways of a man are*i pure in his own eyes, But*ld the Lord*s weighs the spirits.
Commit*ln your works to the Lord,*s And*ld your thoughts will be established.
The*ln Lord*s has made all for Himself, Yes,*ld even the wicked for the day of doom.
Everyone*ln proud in heart is*i an abomination to the Lord;*s Though*ild they*i join*i forces, none will go unpunished.
In*ln mercy and truth Atonement*ld is provided for iniquity; And*ld by the fear of the Lord*s one*i departs from evil.
When*ln a man’s ways please the Lord,*s He*ld makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Better*ln is*i a little with righteousness, Than*ld vast revenues without justice.
A*ln man’s heart plans his way, But*ld the Lord*s directs his steps.
Divination*ln is*i on the lips of the king; His*ld mouth must not transgress in judgment.
Honest*ld weights and scales are*i the Lord’s;*s All*ld the weights in the bag are*i His work.
It*ild is*i an abomination for kings to commit wickedness, For*ld a throne is established by righteousness.
Righteous*ld lips are*i the delight of kings, And*ld they love him who speaks what*i is*i right.
As*ld messengers of death is*i the king’s wrath, But*ld a wise man will appease it.
In*ld the light of the king’s face is*i life, And*ld his favor is*i like a cloud of the latter rain.
How*ln much better to get wisdom than gold! And*ld to get understanding is to be chosen rather than silver.
The*ln highway of the upright is*i to depart from evil; He*ld who keeps his way preserves his soul.
Pride*ln goes*i before destruction, And*ld a haughty spirit before a fall.
Better*ld to*i be*i of a humble spirit with the lowly, Than*ld to divide the spoil with the proud.
He*ln who heeds the word wisely will find good, And*ld whoever trusts in the Lord,*s happy is*i he.
The*ln wise in heart will be called prudent, And*ld sweetness of the lips increases learning.
Understanding*ln is*i a wellspring of life to him who has it. But*ld the correction of fools is*i folly.
The*ln heart of the wise teaches his mouth, And*ld adds learning to his lips.
Pleasant*ln words are*i like*i a honeycomb, Sweetness*ld to the soul and health to the bones.
There*ln is a way that*i seems*i right to a man, But*ld its end is*i the way of death.
The*ln person who labors, labors for himself, For*ld his hungry*i mouth drives him on.*i
An*ln ungodly man digs up evil, And*ld it*i is*i on his lips like a burning fire.
A*ld perverse man sows strife, And*ld a whisperer separates the best of friends.
A*ld violent man entices his neighbor, And*ld leads him in a way that*i is*i not good.
He*ld winks his eye to devise perverse things; He*ld purses his lips and*i brings about evil.
The*ln silver-haired head is*i a crown of glory, If*ild it is found in the way of righteousness.
He*iln who*i is*i slow to anger is*i better than the mighty, And*ld he who rules his spirit than he who takes a city.
The*ln lot is cast into the lap, But*ld its every decision is*i from the Lord.*s
